{{Infobox school | name = Detroit Waldorf School | image = Detroit Waldorf School 1.JPG | alt = | image_size = 250px | caption = Entrance to Detroit Waldorf (east side), 2015 | motto = | location = 2555 Burns, [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | country = {{USA}} | coordinates = {{Coord|42.3645|-82.9975|type:edu|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Michigan#USA | established = 1965 | founders = Rudolf and Amelia Wilhelm<ref name = "cbs"/> | opened = 1966 | closed = | type = [[Waldorf education|Waldorf school]] | district = | grades = PreK - 8th | enrollment = 253 | faculty = | campus_type = Urban | campus_size = {{convert|4|acre|m2}} | team_name = | newspaper = | colors = | communities = | feeders = | website = {{URL|http://www.detroitwaldorf.org/}} | footnotes = {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = [[Indian Village, Detroit|Indian Village]] | nrhp_type = cp | nocat = yes | area = | built = 1913 | architect= [[Albert Kahn (architect)|Albert Kahn]] | architecture= [[Tudor Revival architecture|Tudor Revival]], [[Arts and Crafts movement|Arts and Crafts]] | added = March 24, 1972 | governing_body = Local | refnum=72000667<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2007a}}</ref> | designated_other1 = Michigan State Historic Site | designated_other1_date = September 24, 2016<ref name = "dn2016"/> | designated_other1_number = 2281 | designated_other1_num_position = bottom }} }}
The '''Detroit Waldorf School''' is a private PreK-8 [[Waldorf education|Waldorf school]] located at 2555 Burns, [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] in an [[Albert Kahn (architect)|Albert Kahn]]-designed school in the historic [[Indian Village, Detroit|Indian Village]] neighborhood. In 2016, the building was designated a [[List of Michigan State Historic Sites|Michigan State Historic Site]].<ref name = "dn2016"/> The school is the only remaining private independent school in Detroit,<ref>{{cite newspaper | title = Friends School in Detroit to close because of money woes | author = Ann Zaniewski | newspaper = Detroit Free Press | date = August 28, 2015 | url = http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/detroit/2015/08/27/friends-school-detroit-closing/71275888/}}</ref> and is one of the city's highest-rated schools, receiving five stars on GreatSchools.org.<ref name = "cbs">{{cite web | title = Rare, Independent Detroit School Celebrates 46 Years | date = October 18, 2012 | publisher = CBS Detroit | url = http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2012/10/18/rare-independent-detroit-school-celebrates-46-years/ | accessdate = September 21, 2015}}</ref> As of 2016, 240 students were enrolled in the school.<ref name = "wdet"/>
==Building History== [[File:Eastern Liggett.jpg|thumb|left|Eastern Liggett School c. 1916, showing the original 1913 building]] In 1878, Rev. James D. Liggett settled in Detroit and established a small, independent school for girls, originally known as The Detroit Home and Day School, and later as The Liggett School.<ref name = "ligg">{{cite web| title = Our History | publisher = University Liggett School | url = http://www.uls.org/Page/About-Us/Our-History | accessdate = September 17, 2015}}</ref> The school was originally located at Grand River and Broadway in Detroit, and quickly established itself with many of Detroit's most prominent families. The school incorporated in 1881, with a board of directors that included [[Dexter M. Ferry]], Jacob S. Farrand, and David Whitney, Jr. By 1883, the school had grown from 57 students to 194, and had outgrown its first home. The school moved to a new location at Cass and Stimson.<ref name = "hhh">{{citation | title = Century: The History of the Detroit Liggett School | author = Anne Getz Wormer | publisher = University Liggett School | date = 1981}}</ref> The school continued to grow steadily, and by 1897 had annexed an adjacent house.<ref name = "burton">{{citation | title = The City of Detroit, Michigan, 1701-1922, Volume 1 | editor1 = Clarence Monroe Burton | editor2 = William Stocking | editor3 = Gordon K. Miller | publisher = S. J. Clarke publishing Company | year = 1922 | page = 778 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TUUzAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA778#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> The next year, the school contracted [[Albert Kahn (architect)|Albert Kahn]] to design a gymnasium and other additions to the school, one of Kahn's first professional jobs.<ref name = "hhh"/>
In 1913, the school decided to develop an eastern branch campus to serve students on the city's east side.<ref name = "hhh"/> This site on Indian Village along Charlevoix was chosen, and the school again contracted Albert Kahn to design a new building.<ref name = "burton"/><ref name = "iv">{{citation | title = Historic Indian Village House and Garden Tour | author = Indian Village Association Indian Village Garden Club | publisher = Indian Village Association and Indian Village Garden Club | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=76fhAAAAMAAJ | pages = 17, 18}}</ref> The building is one of only two schools designed by Kahn, and the only one still extant.<ref name = "green">{{cite web | title = Detroit Waldorf School Honored as one of the nation’s 100 "Places that Matter" | publisher = Greening of Detroit | date = June 7, 2011 | url = http://www.greeningdetroit.com/2011/06/07/detroit-waldorf-school-honored-as-one-of-the-nation%E2%80%99s-100-%E2%80%9Cplaces-that-matter%E2%80%9D/ | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref> Kahn's design for the school drew from then-popular English influences,<ref name = "aia">{{citation | title = AIA Detroit: The American Institute of Architects Guide to Detroit Architecture | author1 = Eric J. Hill | author2 = John Gallagher | author3 = American Institute of Architects, Detroit Chapter | publisher = Wayne State University Press | year = 2003 | ISBN = 9780814331200 | page = 270 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sZGskamYzjUC&pg=PA270#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> and was a radical departure from previous school designs, both in his extravagant use of windows and use of stucco rather than brick.<ref name = "iv"/> The building opened the following year as the "Eastern Liggett" branch.<ref name = "burton"/> In 1916, landscape architect [[Ossian Cole Simonds|O. C. Simonds]] designed a landscape plan for the school.<ref name = "dis">{{cite web | title = Dispatch from the Archives: Documenting Liggett | author = Leslie S. Edwards | date = February 2, 2014 | publisher = note information is from University Liggett School Archives | url = https://cranbrookkitchensink.wordpress.com/2014/02/25/dispatch-from-the-archives-documenting-liggett/#more-995 | accessdate = September 21, 2015 }}</ref>
Enrollment at the Eastern Liggett School was 88 in 1913, which rose to 200 by 1919. By the early 1920s, changes in the neighborhood around the Cass Avenue campus led to declining enrollment there. In 1923, the school decided to enlarge the Eastern Liggett building and close the original one.<ref name = "hhh"/> An addition to the school, also designed by Kahn, was constructed in 1924, and houses an auditorium and additional classroom space.<ref name = "iv"/> The addition so closely follows the style of the original building that the difference is nearly imperceptible. Enrollment rose to a high of around 300 students in 1929; although the [[Great Depression]] reduced enrollment, the Liggett School continued to occupy the building until the early 1960s, when the changing nature of Detroit caused the school to decide to move. In 1964, construction began on a new school, and in early 1965, Liggett moved from the Indian Village campus to [[Grosse Pointe Woods, Michigan]]. In 1969, The Liggett School merged with Grosse Pointe University School to form what is now [[University Liggett School]].<ref name = "hhh"/>
==Detroit Waldorf History== [[File:Detroit Waldorf School 2.JPG|thumb|left|Detroit Waldorf School north side, 2015]] The Detroit Waldorf School was founded in 1965 by Rudolf and Amelia Wilhelm,<ref name = "cbs"/> who wanted to provide Detroiters more choices in educating their children.<ref name = "yelp">{{cite web | title = Detroit Waldorf School | publisher = Yelp | url = http://www.yelp.com/biz/detroit-waldorf-school-detroit | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref> Other private schools in the area at the time were not integrated, and the Wilhelms and their supporters sought to provide a diverse educational experience to children.<ref name = "wdet">{{citation| title = Detroit Waldorf School Celebrates 50th Anniversary | date = September 23, 2016 | publisher = WDET: Detroit Today with Stephen Henderson | url = http://wdet.org/posts/2016/09/23/83919-detroit-waldorf-school-celebrates-50th-anniversary/}}</ref> The school approached the board of the [[Central United Methodist Church (Detroit)|Central United Methodist Church]] about allocating space to open a nursery school. An impassioned speech by African-American Junius Harris, where he reminded Board members that families of color had far fewer educational choices for their children, convinced the board to allow the Waldorf nursery school to open in their building.<ref name = "yelp"/> The school opened as a nursery school in the Central United Methodist Church in 1965, and was deliberately integrated from its founding.<ref name = "dn2016"/> However, space in the church was limited, and later that year the school acquired the just-vacated Liggett campus.<ref name = "green"/> Classes for elementary students began at the present school building in September 1966.<ref name = "yelp"/> The Detroit Waldorf School was one of the first nine Waldorf schools in North America, and a founding member of the Association of Waldorf Schools of North America (AWSNA).<ref name = "aws">{{citation | title = AWSNA Timeline, 1965-2010 | author = David Mitchell | publisher = AWSNA | year = 2010 | url = http://www.whywaldorfworks.org/04_AWSNA/documents/AWSNA-8-29-10_(2).pdf}}</ref>
In 1967, Werner and Barbara Glas founded the Waldorf Institute at the school.<ref name = "heart">{{citation | title = Into the Heart's Land | author = Henry Barnes | publisher = SteinerBooks | year = 2005 | ISBN = 9780880108577 | page = 926 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=oRBU8oERXVwC&pg=PT926#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> The Waldorf Institute was the first Waldorf teacher-training institution in the United States, and only the second English-speaking one. In 1979, the Waldorf Institute moved to [[Southfield, Michigan]], and in 1986 moved to [[Chestnut Ridge, New York]].<ref name = "sun">{{cite web | title = History of Sunbridge | publisher = Sunbridge Institute | url = http://www.sunbridge.edu/about/history-of-sunbridge/ | accessdate = September 21, 2015}}</ref> It is now the [[Sunbridge Institute]].
In 2011, the school was selected by the [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]] as one of 100 "places that matter" in the United States.<ref name = "green"/> In 2013, businessman Jeff Adler donated $750,000 to various Detroit organizations, including $100,000 to the Detroit Waldorf School.<ref>{{citation | title = Fond memories inspire California couple to donate $750,000 to Detroit institutions | author = Rochelle Riley | date = October 18, 2013 | newspaper = Detroit Free Press | url = http://archive.freep.com/article/20131018/COL10/310180027/Rochelle-Riley-Fond-memories-inspire-California-couple-donate-750-000-Detroit-institutions}}</ref> In 2016, at the time of the Detroit Waldorf School's 50th anniversary, the school was designated a [[List of Michigan State Historic Sites|Michigan State Historic Site]] A state of Michigan historical marker was erected at the school commemorating both the original occupant of the building, Eastern Liggett School, and Detroit Waldorf School.<ref name = "dn2016">{{cite news | title = Detroit’s Waldorf School gets historic marker | author = Karen Bouffard | newspaper = The Detroit News | date = September 24, 2016 | url = http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/detroit-city/2016/09/24/waldorf-school-historic-marker/91033840/}}</ref>
The Detroit Waldorf School has maintained a commitment to providing a strong [[Waldorf education]] children in Detroit,<ref name = "cbs"/> and to racial, ethnic, geographic, and social-economic diversity in its student body.<ref name = "wdet"/><ref name = "dn2016"/> The school has remained at its present location since 1966. {{clear}}
==Education in the Early Childhood Center== The Detroit Waldorf School Early Childhood Center includes Pre-K classes for children 3-5 and full-day Kindergarten. The focus in the Early Childhood Center is on language and stories in circle/story time, and on indoor and outdoor creative free play. The school believes that free play is a fundamental part of early learning, fostering imagination, creativity, problem solving and social skills which aid in academic learning in later years. Children in the Early Childhood Center experience movement in play, including skipping, jumping rope, and [[eurythmy]]. They also do arts and handwork, including coloring, painting, modeling with beeswax, and baking bread.<ref name = "ec">{{cite web | title = The Early Childhood Center | publisher = Detroit Waldorf School | url = http://www.detroitwaldorf.org/early-childhood | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref>
==Elementary and Middle School Academics== Beginning in elementary school, the core academic subjects (language arts, mathematics, science, and social studies) are presented in a two-hour main lesson each day. The subject of the main lesson rotates every three to four weeks. The school believes that presenting material in blocks lets students explore the material more deeply.<ref name = "curr">{{cite web | title = Curriculum | publisher = Detroit Waldorf School | url = http://www.detroitwaldorf.org/curriculum/ | accessdate = September 20, 2015}}</ref>
In addition to the core academic subjects, students also learn two foreign languages (Spanish and German),<ref name = "one">{{cite web | title = Grades 1-5 | publisher = Detroit Waldorf School | url = http://www.detroitwaldorf.org/1-5-grade | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref> as well as music, movement, arts, and handwork.<ref name = "glim">{{cite web | title = A Glimpse through the Grades Curriculum| publisher = Detroit Waldorf School | url = https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/264912244/CurriculumGuide.pdf/ | accessdate = September 20, 2015}}</ref> The curriculum integrates the traditional academic subjects with the arts to provide engaging experiences for the student. The school aims to not only educate students, but also to prepare them to be creative, critical thinkers with individual initiative.<ref name = "gs">{{cite web | title = Detroit Waldorf School | publisher = Great Schools | url = http://www.greatschools.org/michigan/detroit/4273-Detroit-Waldorf-School/ | accessdate = September 20, 2015}}</ref>
'''Language Arts''' begins with an introduction to letters, reading, and handwriting in the first grade. It continues through spelling and grammar, further reading, research and creative writing, poetry, and composition. Students read stories, fables, and literature, culminating in a Shakespearean play in eighth grade. Each grade also puts on a class play.<ref name = "one"/><ref name = "glim"/><ref name = "six">{{cite web | title = Grades 6-8 | publisher = Detroit Waldorf School | url = http://www.detroitwaldorf.org/6-8-grade | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref>
'''Mathematics''' starts with basic arithmetic and the introduction to numbers, and continues with multiplication, division, fractions, exponents, and roots. Geometry is taught in the middle and upper grades. The upper grades begin studying business math, pre-algebra, and algebra, including graphing equations.<ref name = "one"/><ref name = "glim"/><ref name = "six"/>
'''Science''' is introduced in the lower grades through observation and experience with nature, as well as gardening and cooking. Science continues in the middle grades with zoology, botany, and astronomy, and in the upper grades with physics, chemistry, anatomy, mechanics, and meteorology.<ref name = "one"/><ref name = "glim"/><ref name = "six"/>
'''Social Studies''' begins in the earlier grades with legends, myths, and folklore. It segues to local and world geography, and history from ancient Greek history through Medieval and Renaissance times to the present.<ref name = "one"/><ref name = "glim"/><ref name = "six"/>
'''Foreign Language''' includes both Spanish and German. Teaching the languages parallels what students learn in Language Arts; this includes reading, conversation, and composition.<ref name = "one"/><ref name = "glim"/><ref name = "six"/>
'''Music''' begins with singing. Singing continues through later grades in chorus. All students also learn to play musical instruments. The early grades use a flute and recorder; the upper grades begin with stringed instruments and eventually into orchestra.<ref name = "one"/><ref name = "glim"/><ref name = "six"/>
'''Movement and Physical Education''' is introduced in the form of games and [[eurythmy]]. Gymnastics is introduced later, as well as dancing and team sports.<ref name = "one"/><ref name = "glim"/><ref name = "six"/>
'''Art and Handwork''' is introduced with painting, drawing, knitting, and beeswax modeling. As students progress, more sophisticated painting and drawing is introduced, as well as carving, pottery, sculpture, cross-stitch, sewing, carpentry, and woodworking.<ref name = "one"/><ref name = "glim"/><ref name = "six"/>
==After School Programs== The school offers various after-school programs for students. These include competitive sports, physical activities, musical instruction, and Games. 2015/2016 offerings include basketball, track, soccer, tennis, volleyball, circus arts, kinderharp, guitar, brain games, and chess.<ref name = "as">{{cite web | title = After School Programs | publisher = Detroit Waldorf School | url = http://www.detroitwaldorf.org/after-school-programs/ | accessdate = September 21, 2015}}</ref>
==Accreditation== The Detroit Waldorf School is accredited by the Independent Schools Association of the Central States (ISACS),<ref name = "iscas">{{cite web | title = Find a School : Geographical Listing | publisher = ISACS | url = http://www.isacs.org/page/472117_Geographical_Listing.asp?sortby=state&id=MI&lat=44.59&lng=-86.15&zoom=6 | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref> the Association of Waldorf Schools of North America (AWSNA),<ref name = "awsna">{{cite web | title = Member School List | publisher = AWSNA| url = http://www.whywaldorfworks.org/05_FindASchool/index.php?group_type=allschools&group_country=us&state=MI | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref> and the Waldorf Early Childhood Association of North America (WECAN).<ref name = "wecan">{{cite web | title = WECAN Directory | publisher = WECAN| url = http://www.waldorfearlychildhood.org/directory.php?country=&state=MI&Membership_Status= | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref>
==Alumni== Notable alumni of the Detroit Waldorf School include:<ref name = "alum">{{cite web | title = Alumni | publisher = Detroit Waldorf School | url = http://www.detroitwaldorf.org/alumni/ | accessdate = September 19, 2015}}</ref> *[[Big Sean]], ''hip-hop artist'': Big Sean credits the school with teaching him "to be open-minded and creative."<ref>{{citation | title = Fresh Perspective | magazine = Complex | author = Damien Scott | date = February 2015 | url = http://www.complex.com/covers/big-sean-interview-2015-cover-story/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Big Sean Talks Growing Up In Detroit, Being 'Finally Famous' | author = Simone Landon | publisher = Huffington Post | date = Nov 18, 2011 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/18/big-sean-interview-detroit-finally-famous_n_1101304.html | accessdate = September 21, 2015}}</ref> *[[Scott Boman]], ''Libertarian politician'' *Cybelle Codish,'' photojournalist'' *Chris Codish, ''composer and musician'' *John Duffey Leo, ''actor'' *Crystal McCrary Anthony, ''model, actress, and producer'' *[[Sufjan Stevens]], ''singer-songwriter'' *[[Veronica Webb]], ''model-actress'' *Jaime Moyer, ''actress/comedian''
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Detroit]] [[Category:Tudor Revival architecture in Michigan]] [[Category:Private elementary schools in Michigan]] [[Category:Private middle schools in Michigan]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1965]] [[Category:Schools in Wayne County, Michigan]] [[Category:Waldorf schools in the United States]] [[Category:Historic district contributing properties in Michigan]]

revision.text:
{{About|the academic administrator||Douglas Lynch (disambiguation){{!}}Douglas Lynch}} {{Underlinked|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Doug Lynch | birth_name = | image =Doug Lynch (cropped).jpg | image_size = 150px | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|05|07}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = | years_active = | spouse = | awards = }}
'''Douglas E. Lynch''' is an academic administrator and education entrepreneur who has made significant contributions to education innovation and also sparked controversy.
== Background == Lynch holds a B.A. in economics from [[Arizona State University]], an M.B.A. in International Finance from the [[New York University Stern School of Business|Stern School of Business at New York University]],<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/almanac/v50/n31/lynD.html|title = Vice Dean at Graduate School of Education: Doug Lynch|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and an M.Phil. and Ph.D. in Economics and Education from [[Columbia University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://academiccommons.columbia.edu/catalog/ac:155034|title = Does Diversity Matter?: Evidence from the Relationship Between an Institution's Diversity and the Salaries of its Graduates|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
Doug was the vice dean at the Graduate School of Education at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] and while there also served for a time as an academic director of Wharton Executive Education and a senior adviser to the [[Fels Institute of Government]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/pennnews/news/eric-rabe-join-penn-s-fels-institute-government-research-consulting-senior-advisor|title = Eric Rabe to Join Penn's Fels Institute of Government Research & Consulting as Senior Advisor|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://beacon.wharton.upenn.edu/remurphy/2009/04/distributed-learning-roundtabl/|title = Distributed Learning Roundtable: The importance of story and design|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/almanac/v50/n31/lynD.html|title = Vice Dean at Graduate School of Education: Doug Lynch|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Prior to Penn, Doug was an assistant dean at New York University and before joining NYU, Doug worked at the [[College Board]] and Arizona State University.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/almanac/v50/n31/lynD.html|title = http://www.upenn.edu/almanac/v50/n31/lynD.html|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Work in Education Innovation == During his time at ASU, Lynch helped launch the Genesis Academy as a [[charter school]]; one of the first in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/almanac/v50/n31/lynD.html|title = Vice Dean at Graduate School of Education: Doug Lynch|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> At NYU, Lynch became active in adult & continuing education with a specific focus on online education. He was invited to present testimony to the U.S. Congress.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www2.ed.gov/offices/AC/WBEC/FinalReport/Appendices.pdf|title = Appendices|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> In 2002, Lynch's work at NYU in exporting education was recognized by the U.S. Department of Commerce though a [[President's "E" Award]] in exporting; the first time a college was recognized for innovation in exporting.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.clomedia.com/events|title = CLO Media Events|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
At Penn he has launched a handful of new endeavors including the first joint doctoral program in work-based learning (with the Wharton School) and the executive masters for Teach for America corps members serving Philadelphia as well as an education business plan competition.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/gazette/0111/feature1_1.html|title = Meet Doug Lynch, the vice dean bent on making Penn GSE a hub for social entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, and next-generation educational reform.|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Lynch also launched GSE films and the first movie he produced won a "Teddy" Award for best documentary.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.gse.upenn.edu/content/freedom-school-documentary-wins-telly-award|title = Freedom School Documentary Wins Telly Award|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> He also launched the NEST and the Milken Business Plan Competition, the largest education business plan competition in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/gazette/0111/feature1_1.html|title = Meet Doug Lynch, the vice dean bent on making Penn GSE a hub for social entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, and next-generation educational reform.|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> He was invited to serve on American Enterprise Institute's Future of Education Reform as well as Harvard's Futures of Education Reform Initiative.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.edweek.org/ew/collections/futures-of-school-reform/whoswho.html|title = The Futures of School Reform: Who's Who|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> In 2012, Lynch did a TED Talk on innovation and was also selected as one of the most important education scholars.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.ted.com/tedx/events/2439|title = Theme: Imagining Reality|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Work in Corporate Learning == At NYU, Lynch created "Corporate Learning Services" to serve employers learning needs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://nycfuture.org/research/publications/a-workforce-vision-for-continuing-education|title = A WORKFORCE VISION FOR CONTINUING EDUCATION|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Working with [[Richard C. Breeden|Richard Breeden]], Lynch designed and delivered all the training for [[MCI Inc.|WorldCom]] to help it emerge from sanctions and bankruptcy.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://anitacrawley.net/Articles/Sloan2011vol6_eqoe_engaging_communities_0.pdf|title = Elements of Quality Online Education Engaging Communities|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> He also was brought in after 9/11 to help [[New York City Fire Department]] design programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://repository.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1035&context=gse_pubs&sei-redir=1&referer=http%253A%252F%252Fwww.google.com%252Furl%253Fsa%253Dt%2526rct%253Dj%2526q%253Dfdnyu%20lynch%2526source%253Dweb%2526cd%253D1%2526ved%253D0CDIQFjAA%2526url%253Dhttp%253A%252F%252Frepository.upenn.edu%252Fcgi%252Fviewcontent.cgi%253Farticle%253D1035%2526context%253Dgse_pubs%2526ei%253DuxsRUdiFO8my0QGb9IDQCA%2526usg%253DAFQjCNHOa5dMEelc2P4T6olSylnQUZIdtA%2526sig2%253DIK4Svb1wdWzrxl71-gn9Iw%23search=%2522fdnyu%2520lynch%2522|title = Success Versus Value: What Do We Mean by the Business of Online Education?|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> At Penn, he created the first doctoral program designed for Chief Learning Officers.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/gazette/0111/feature1_1.html|title = Meet Doug Lynch, the vice dean bent on making Penn GSE a hub for social entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, and next-generation educational reform.|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> He was the chair of the [[American Society for Training & Development]] Public Policy Committee,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.td.org/Publications/Magazines/TD/TD-Archive/2009/04/Doug-Lynch|title = Doug Lynch|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and also chaired the US delegation to the International Standards Organization in an effort to establish global standards for all non-formal learning.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.td.org/Publications/Newsletters/Links/2007/05/ASTD-Working-to-Promote-International-Standards-for-Education-and-Training|title = ASTD Working to Promote International Standards for Education and Training|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> As an expert in corporate learning, Lynch also served for a time on the Board of Visitors to the [[Central Intelligence Agency]]'s Corporate University.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.td.org/Publications/Magazines/TD/TD-Archive/2009/04/Doug-Lynch|title = Doug Lynch|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> In 2001, one of his programs at NYU won an HR Executive "Top 10" Award and in 2003, another program won an APX Award for Program.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.teachpedia.com/topics/NYU-School-of-Continuing-and-Professional-Studies?PHPSESSID=vl0e1375svh1op7puvl4f1fcg5%20google|title = School of Continuing and Professional Studies|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Controversy == In 2012, Lynch was accused of falsifying his doctorate, with an article alleging he claimed dates for a Masters in Philosophy that was not correct and for a PhD that he had not yet completed.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://abcnews.go.com/US/upenn-dean-faked-phd-ivy-league/story?id=16229174|title = University of Pennsylvania Dean Faked PhD|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Lynch resigned one day after the story broke in the national press. Another article that followed the controversy noted that the Penn website did not list his degrees, only that on one Penn website he was referred to as "Dr." Lynch,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thedp.com/article/2012/04/gse_vice_dean_resigns_amid_false_degree_claims|title = GSE vice dean resigns amid false degree claims|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and in another article, it notes that he claimed he was "trained in economics" rather than having a doctorate.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://abcnews.go.com/US/upenn-dean-faked-phd-ivy-league/story?id=16229174|title = University of Pennsylvania Dean Faked PhD|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.ted.com/tedx/events/2439|title = Theme: Imagining Reality|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Penn Press release at the time of his hire, did not mention either degree but rather that he was enrolled in a doctoral program.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.upenn.edu/almanac/v50/n31/lynD.html|title = Vice Dean at Graduate School of Education: Doug Lynch|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The controversy continued a year later, where another article claimed that he continued to fake his degrees.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thedp.com/article/2013/01/former-penn-admin-continues-to-lie-about-credentials|title = Former GSE admin Doug Lynch continues to falsify credentials|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> However, the Columbia University website at the time of the article did listed him as having a PhD and with a dissertation in economics that focused on the value of diversity.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://academiccommons.columbia.edu/catalog/ac:155034|title = Does Diversity Matter?: Evidence from the Relationship Between an Institution's Diversity and the Salaries of its Graduates|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Interviews and Citations in the Press== * CLO Magazine February 9, 2012. How [http://www.clomedia.com/articles/how-failure-resumes-can-boost-leadership-development ‘Failure Resumes’ Can Boost Leadership Development] * CLO Magazine February 8, 2012. [http://www.clomedia.com/articles/follow-the-leader Follow The Leader: The Most Sought After Skills For Global Leaders] * CLO Magazine, February 1, 2012. [http://www.clomedia.com/articles/back-to-school-changes-in-executive-education Back To School. Changes In Executive Education] * Learning Matters Podcast, December 6, 2012. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rRafKet04VI Doug Lynch On Business And Education] * Education Week, June 13, 2011. [http://www.marketplace.org/topics/life/colleges-bid-nyc-space Colleges Bid for NYC Space] * Education Week, January 25, 2011. [http://blogs.edweek.org/edweek/inside-school-research/2011/01/the_next_iteration_of_i3_from.html?print=1 The Next Iteration Of I3: From Symphony To Jazz?] * Inside Higher Ed, June 14, 2011. [https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2011/06/14/penn_s_education_school_holds_a_business_plan_competition_for_educational_ventures Ed School Business] * Governing Magazine. October 2010. [http://www.governing.com/columns/dispatch/resiliance-procurement-reform-Georgia.html The Resilience Of Procurement Reform In Georgia] * USA Today. July 27, 2010. [http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/education/2010-07-27-technology-test-entrepreneurs_N.htm Programs, $650m Fund Help Entrepreneurs In Education Market] * E-School News. June 1, 2009. [http://www.eschoolnews.com/2009/06/01/school-of-the-future-lessons-in-failure/ School Of The Future: Lessons In Failure] * Training & Development Magazine April 2009. [http://www.docstoc.com/docs/42955441/THE-LONG-VIEW--DOUG-LYNCH The Long View: Doug Lynch] * Training & Development Magazine, March 2009. [https://www.td.org/Publications/Magazines/TD/TD-Archive/2009/03/Leadership-Development-One-Size-Does-Not-Fit-All Leadership Development: One Size Does Not Fit All] * Workforce Magazine, March 2009. [http://www.workforce.com/articles/create-a-winning-team Tough Times Bring Clients To Disney's Training Business]

revision.text:
[[File:GlassFlowers1HMNH.jpg|thumb|upright=1|right|Blaschka glass model of part of a [[cashew]] tree]]
'''The Ware Collection of Blaschka Glass Models of Plants''' (or simply the '''''Glass Flowers''''') is a collection of highly realistic [[glass]] [[botany|botanical]] models at the [[Harvard Museum of Natural History]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].
Created by [[Leopold and Rudolf Blaschka]] from 1887 through 1936 at their studio in [[Hosterwitz]], near [[Dresden, Germany]], the collection was commissioned by [[George Lincoln Goodale]], the first director of Harvard's [[Botanical Museum]], and was financed by [[Mary Lee Ware]] and her mother [[Elizabeth Cabot (Lee) Ware|Elizabeth C. Ware]].<ref>Blaschka Plants Blend Science and Artistry (NYT) - https://www.nytimes.com/1976/03/08/archives/new-jersey-pages-blaschka-plants-blend-science-and-artistry.html?_r=0</ref> It includes 847 life-size models (representing 780 species and varieties of plants in 164 families) and some 3,000 detail models such as of plant parts and anatomical sections. The collection comprises approximately 4,400 individual glass models representing over 830 plant species.
==Background== {{main|Leopold and Rudolf Blaschka}} [[File:Rudolf, Leopold and Caroline Blaschka in garden cropped.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|left|Rudolf (standing) and Leopold Blaschka]] Starting in 1863 the Blaschkas had a thriving business making glass models of [[marine invertebrate]]s, selling them to museums and private collectors in a global enterprise (see {{crossreference|[[Glass sea creatures]]}}).<ref>http://news.cornell.edu/stories/2016/10/exhibition-talk-film-explore-sea-glass</ref> Then, in 1886, the Blaschkas were approached by Professor Goodale who, after seeing their work, had gone Dresden to ask them to make a series of glass botanical models for Harvard; the reason for the request being that only used method at time was showcasing pressed and carefully labeled specimens—a methodology that offered a twofold problem: being pressed, the specimens were two-dimensional and tended to lose their color, two drawbacks which glass models did not have.<ref name="hmnh.harvard.edu">http://hmnh.harvard.edu/glass-flowers</ref><ref name="nasonline.org">http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/goodale-george.pdf National Academy of Sciences Biographical Memoir</ref> Leopold was hesitant but eventually agreed to make some sample models which, though badly damaged in customs,<ref>http://www.cmog.org/article/glass-flowers</ref> convinced Goodale of their value in botanical teaching.<ref name="hmnh.harvard.edu"/><ref name="nasonline.org"/><ref name="nasonline.org"/>
To fund the project Goodale approached his former student Mary Lee Ware and her mother, Elizabeth [[Cabot family|C.]] Ware, who were already liberal benefactors of Harvard's botanical department.<ref>Flowers that never fade / Franklin Baldwin Wiley. Boston Bradlee Whidden, Publisher 1897</ref> The original arrangement (in 1887) provided that the Blaschkas would work half time on the project, but in 1890 a new arrangement called for them to work full-time.<ref name="Schultes, Richard Evans 1982">Schultes, Richard Evans., William A. Davis, and Hillel Burger. The Glass Flowers at Harvard. New York: Dutton, 1982. Print.</ref><ref>The Archives of Rudolph and Leopold Blaschka and the Ware Collection of Blaschka Glass Models of Plants - http://botlib.huh.harvard.edu/libraries/glass.htm</ref> The work continued until 1936, at which point Leopold and Elizabeth had both died.<ref name="nasonline.org"/>
The collection is formally dedicated to [[Charles Eliot Ware|Dr. Charles Eliot Ware]], the deceased father and husband of Mary and Elizabeth Ware, respectively.<ref name="hmnh.harvard.edu"/>
==The models== [[File:Ware Dedication plaque.jpg|right|thumb|upright=1|"In memory of physician Charles Eliot Ware (1814{{ndash}}1887), a graduate of this university. These models were presented by his wife and daughter who survived him. He sincerely cherished and deeply loved native plants as friends."]] The models are glass with wire supports (internal or external), glue, a variety of organic media,{{Explain|date=March 2017}} and paint or enamel coloring.<ref>NcNally, Rika Smith and Nancy Buschini (1993). [http://aic.stanford.edu/jaic/articles/jaic32-03-002_1.html Journal of the American Institute for Conservation], Volume 32, Number 3, Article 2 (pp. 231 to 240)</ref> The ''Boston Globe'' has called them "anatomically perfect and, given all the glass-workers who've tried and failed, unreproducible."<ref>Putting the Glass Flowers in new light - http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2016/05/putting-the-glass-flowers-in-new-light/</ref><ref>Harvard's glass flowers return - https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/theater-art/2016/05/24/harvard-glass-flowers-return/SwICUX1ZgpsP3CPPeMbpuO/story.html</ref>
[[File:GlassFlowers4HMNH.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.4]]
It is often said that the Blaschkas employed secret techniques now lost; in fact their techniques were common at the time, but their skill, enthusiasm, and meticulous study and observation of their subjects in life were extraordinary, which Leopold ascribed to familial tradition, in a letter to Mary Lee Ware: "Many people think that we have some secret apparatus by which we can squeeze glass suddenly into these forms{{nbsp}} ... <!--, but it is not so. We have tact. My son Rudolf has more than I have, because he is my son, and tact increases in every generation.--> The only way to become a glass modeler of skill, I have often said to people, is to get a good great-grandfather who loved glass."
The Blaschkas' primary technique was [[lampworking]], in which glass is melted over a flame fed by air from a foot-powered bellows, then shaped using tools to pinch, pull or cut; forms were blown as well.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glass Dictionary|url=http://www.cmog.org/research/glass-dictionary/l|publisher=Corning Museum of Glass|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref> Their old-fashioned Bohemian lamp-working table is part of the museum exhibit. Over the years Rudolf brought more and more of the entire production process under his personal control, eventually even manufacturing his own glass and colorants.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Zone Books| isbn = 978-1-890951-43-6| last = Daston| first = Lorraine| title = Things that talk : object lessons from art and science| chapter = The Glass Flowers| location = New York| date = 2004}}</ref>
Botanist Donald Schnell has called the models "enchanting", and relates his surprise at finding that the models faithfully depict an unpublished detail of a bee's behavior while pollinating a particular plant{{emdash}}a detail which he had privately hypothesized.<ref>Schnell, Donald (2002). Carnivorous Plants of the United States and Canada. Timber Press. {{ISBN|0-88192-540-3}}.</ref> Whitehouse and Small wrote that "the superiority in design and construction of the Blaschka models surpasses all modern model making to date and the skill and art of the Blaschkas rests in peace for eternity."{{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
==Public response== [[File:GlassFlowers2HMNH.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.8|Cactus model]] The Glass Flowers is one of the most noted tourist attractions of the Boston area. More than 210,000 visitors view the collection annually. In 1936, when Harvard invited the public to tour the campus in honor of its tercentenary, a ''[[New York Times]]'' reporter taking the tour commented "Tercentenary or no, the chief focus of interest remains the famous glass flowers, the first of which was put on exhibition in 1893, and which with additions at intervals since, have never failed to draw exclamations of wonder or disbelief from visitors."<ref name="NY Times">{{cite news |url= |publisher=The New York Times |title=Back to Back Bay After an Absence of Ten Years |date=June 10, 1951 |page=XX17 }}</ref> Many visitors initially believe the Glass Flowers to be real, organic, plants and soon after entering or leaving exhibition inquire "where are the glass flowers?"<ref>Geoffrey N. Swinney & (2008) Enchanted invertebrates: Blaschka models and other simulacra in National Museums Scotland, Historical Biology, 20:1, 39-50, DOI: 10.1080/08912960701677036 - https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/08912960701677036</ref><ref>Rossi-Wilcox SM. 2008. From reference specimen to Verisimilitude: the Blaschkas' penchant for botanical accuracy. Hist Biol 20(1):11–18.</ref>
At least two poems feature the flowers:
[[Mark Doty]] (winner of the [[National Book Award]] for Poetry in 2008), "The Ware Collection of Glass Flowers and Fruit, Harvard Museum", in ''My Alexandria'', 1993,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cabinetmagazine.org/issues/6/vitreoustact.php|title=CABINET // Great Vitreous Tact|work=cabinetmagazine.org}}</ref>
{{poemquote|He's built a perfection out of hunger, fused layer upon layer, swirled until what can't be tasted, won't yield, almost satisfies, an art mouthed to the shape of how soft things are, how good, before they disappear.}}
[[Marianne Moore]] wrote in a poem, "Silence",
{{poemquote|My father used to say, "Superior people never make long visits, have to be shown Longfellow's grave, or the glass flowers at Harvard."}}
==See also== *[[Artificial flowers]] *[[Glassblowing]] *[[Lampworking]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=35em}}
==External links== * {{Cite web |url=http://hmnh.harvard.edu/glass-flowers |title=The Ware Collection of Blaschka Glass Models of Plants |website= Harvard website }} *[http://exhibits.mannlib.cornell.edu/blaschka/ Invertebrate Models at Cornell University] *{{cite web|title=The Glass Flowers|url=http://www.cmog.org/article/glass-flowers|website=Corning Museum of Glass|publisher=Corning Museum of Glass|accessdate=5 June 2014|date=18 October 2011}} *[http://www.cmog.org/research/library/collections/digital/blaschka The Blaschka Archives], held by the Rakow Library of the Corning Museum of Glass. Retrieved 5 June 2014. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rHOx5H5vNx4 The Story of Rudolf and Leopold Blaschka] * [http://hmnh.harvard.edu/glass-flowers The Glass Flowers (Harvard)] * [http://www.cmog.org/article/glass-flowers The Glass Flowers (Corning)] * [http://news.psu.edu/story/140881/1999/09/01/research/flowers-out-glass Flowers Out of Glass (Penn State)] * [https://www.jstor.org/stable/41762212 How Were The Glass Flowers Made?] {{Commons category|position=left|Harvard University Glass Flowers}}
{{Harvard|state=collapsed}}

/* See also */ Adding Methodology
revision.text:
[[File:BloomsCognitiveDomain.svg|right|thumb|250px|Categories in the cognitive domain of [[Bloom's taxonomy]] (Anderson & Krathwohl, 2001)]] '''Higher-order thinking''', known as '''higher order thinking skills''' ('''HOTS'''), is a concept of [[education reform]] based on learning [[Taxonomy (general)|taxonomies]] (such as [[Bloom's taxonomy]]). The idea is that some types of learning require more cognitive processing than others, but also have more generalized benefits. In Bloom's taxonomy, for example, skills involving analysis, evaluation and synthesis (creation of new knowledge) are thought to be of a higher order, requiring different learning and teaching methods than the learning of facts and concepts. Higher-order thinking involves the learning of complex judgmental skills such as [[critical thinking]] and problem solving. Higher-order thinking is more difficult to learn or teach but also more valuable because such skills are more likely to be usable in novel situations (i.e., situations other than those in which the skill was learned). ==Education reform== It is a notion that students must [[Mastery learning|master the lower level skills]] before they can engage in higher-order thinking. However, the United States [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] objected to this line of reasoning, saying that cognitive research challenges that assumption, and that higher-order thinking is important even in elementary school.{{cite book |last=Resnick |first=Lauren B. |date=1987 |title=Education and learning to think |location=Washington, DC |publisher=[[National Academy Press]] |isbn=0309037859 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_zYrAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA8 8]}} Including higher-order thinking skills in [[educational aims and objectives]] is a very common feature of [[standards-based education reform]]. Advocates of [[traditional education]] object to elevating HOTS above direct instruction of [[basic skills]]. Many forms of education reform, such as inquiry-based science, [[reform mathematics]] and [[whole language]] emphasize HOTS to solve problems and learn, sometimes deliberately omitting direct instruction of traditional methods, facts, or knowledge. HOTS assumes [[standards based assessment]]s that use open-response items instead of multiple choice questions, and hence require higher-order analysis and writing. Critics of [[standards based assessment]]s point out that this style of testing is even more difficult for students who are behind academically. Indeed, while minorities may lag by 10 to 25 points on standardized percentile rankings, the failure rates of minorities are two to four times the best scoring groups on tests like the [[Washington Assessment of Student Learning|WASL]]. It is debated whether it is correct to raise the importance of teaching process over content.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The [[Republican Party of Texas]] expressed their opposition to the teaching of certain HOTS by including the following item in their 2012 Party Platform:{{cite web|title=Texas Republican Party Platform of 2012 |publisher=[[Republican Party of Texas]] |url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/texasgop_pre/assets/original/2012-Platform-Final.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629111643/http://s3.amazonaws.com/texasgop_pre/assets/original/2012-Platform-Final.pdf |archivedate=29 June 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}
"Knowledge-Based Education – We oppose the teaching of Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS) (values clarification), critical thinking skills and similar programs that are simply a relabeling of Outcome-Based Education (OBE) (mastery learning) which focus on behavior modification and have the purpose of challenging the student's fixed beliefs and undermining parental authority."
However, the final wording of this item was evidently a "mistake" according to Republican Party of Texas Communications Director Chris Elam who said, in an interview with ''[[Talking Points Memo]]'', that the plank should not have included the phrase "critical thinking skills" and it was not the intent of the subcommittee to indicate that the RPT was opposed to critical thinking skills. When asked to clarify the meaning of the item he said, "I think the intent is that the Republican Party is opposed to the values clarification method that serves the purpose of challenging students beliefs and undermine {{sic}} parental authority".{{cite web |last=Lach |first=Eric |url=http://tpmmuckraker.talkingpointsmemo.com/2012/06/texas_gops_2012_platform_accidentally_opposes_teaching_of_critical_thinking_skills.php |title=Texas GOP's 2012 platform opposes teaching of 'critical thinking skills' |website=[[Talking Points Memo]] |date=29 June 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2016}} == Mathematics == Similarly, [[textbook]]s such as Dale Seymour's Investigations omit many standard [[arithmetic]] methods, instead relying on students to construct their own ways to compute [[average]]s, and perform [[multiplication]] and [[Division (mathematics)|division]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2016}} Teachers are directed to discourage students who may have been taught how to regroup or take a sum and divide by the number of items to compute an average. == See also == * [[DIKW pyramid]] * [[Fluid and crystallized intelligence]] * [[Integrative complexity]] * [[Metacognition]] * [[Methodology]] * [[Model of hierarchical complexity]] * [[Structure of observed learning outcome]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Higher-Order Thinking}} [[Category:Education reform]] [[Category:Critical thinking skills]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox university |name = Ho Chi Minh City University of Economics and Finance (UEF) |image_name = Ho_Chi_Minh_City_University_of_Economics_and_Finance_UEF_Logo.png |motto = Quality, Efficiency, Integration |established = 24 September 2007 |address = 276, Dien Bien Phu. Binh Thanh district. |state = [[Ho Chi Minh City]] |country = [[Vietnam]] |website = {{URL|http://www.uef.edu.vn/}} }}
The '''Ho Chi Minh City University of Economics and Finance''' ('''UEF''') is a Vietnamese private university based in [[Ho Chi Minh City]], [[Vietnam]]. Its main branch is located at: 276 Dien Bien Phu, District Binh Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City. {{TOC limit|2}}
==Facilities==
Ho Chi Minh City University of Economics and Finance is located near the center of town (5 minutes drive to the Central Business District). It has modern equipment in a tower of 16 floors and 2 basement floors.
* Classrooms fully equipped with air-conditioning, computers, projectors and Wifi * Information Technology classrooms with individual desktops for each student * A library with all the books the students need for their studies * A Self-studying and social area for students to relax in their free time * A fitness center with coach Ly Duc ([[Bodybuilding at the 2002 Asian Games – Men's 80 kg|2002 Asian Games Bodybuilding Champion]])
[[File:UEF - OVERVIEW.jpg|thumb|UEF]]
==Academic programs==
The curricula provided at the UEF are relevant to modern day business life. The teaching methods focus on student interaction, teamwork, discussions and presentations. Other than that, students are brought to cultivate problem solving and creative thinking skills. And to be sure all the students acquire the skills taught, the classes are designed to accommodate no more than 30 students.
===Business Administration=== * General Management * [[Small and medium-sized enterprises|Small and Medium-sized Enterprises]] Management * Entrepreneurship * Logistics Management
===International Business=== * International Management * Foreign Trade
===Marketing=== * Marketing Management * Branding * Advertising
===Business Law=== * International Commerce Law * Business Law * Law of Finance and Banking
===E-Commerce=== * Online business * Online Marketing
===Finance and Banking=== * Banking * Business Finance * Public Finance * Investment Finance
===Accounting=== * Accounting * Business Accounting
===Information Technology=== * IT Security * Web technologies * Software * Networking
===English=== * Business English * English Translation * Academic English
===Public Relations=== * Event Management and Coordination * News Media
===Hospitality Management=== * Hospitality Management * Hospitality and Tourism Management * Hospitality and Restaurant Management
===Human Resource Management===
==International exchange programs==
The Ho Chi Minh City University of Economics and Finance has partnerships with the University of Pittsburgh (USA) and the University of Bangkok (Thailand).<ref>http://www.uef.edu.vn/en/student-activities/plus-3-2016-students-of-uef-and-pitt-learn-from-visits-to-corporations-2297</ref><ref>http://www.uef.edu.vn/en/student-activities/uef-s-students-eagerly-explores-bangkok-university-thailand-2286</ref>
==Internships and employment for students==
Alongside with the Academic process, the UEF keeps strong ties with the business world. In that matter, students are offered internship and professional opportunities at UEF's partner companies in sectors such as banking ([[Sacombank]], [[HSBC]], [[Joint Stock Commercial Bank for Foreign Trade of Vietnam|Vietcombank]], [[Australia and New Zealand Banking Group|ANZ]]), retail (Nguyen Kim, [[AEON (company)|AEON]]) or corporate services ([[KPMG]]).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.uef.edu.vn Official Vietnamese website] * [http://www.uef.edu.vn/en Official English website] * [http://www.uef.edu.vn/vdtqt-en Institute of International Education]
{{coord missing|Vietnam}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Idit Harel | image = Idit Harel 2015.JPG | image_size = 250px | caption = | birth_name = Idit Ron | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|9|18|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = United States | field = [[Edtech]]
[[Entrepreneurship]]
[[Social Entrepreneurship]]
[[Innovation]]
[[Learning Sciences]]
[[Developmental psychology|Human Development]] | work_institutions = | alma_mater = {{nowrap|[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]}}
{{nowrap|[[Harvard University]]}}
{{nowrap|[[Tel Aviv University]]}} | known_for = [[MaMaMedia, Inc.]]
[[Globaloria]]
[http://www.worldwideworkshop.org World Wide Workshop]}} '''Idit R. Harel''' (born '''Idit Ron'''; September 18, 1958) is an [[Israeli Americans|Israeli-American]] entrepreneur and CEO of [[Globaloria]]. She is a [[learning sciences]] researcher and pioneer of [[Constructionist learning]]-based [[EdTech]] interventions. ==Overview== Harel researches and writes on the impact of computational [[new media]] technology on the social and academic development of children and their [[epistemology]]. Her [[MIT Media Lab]] research with [[Seymour Papert]] has contributed to the development of [[constructionist learning]] theory. She blogs monthly on Huffington Post Impact and Technology verticals on computer skills education, particularly for young women, girls, and underprivileged children, and the value of [[MOOC]]s in education reform.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/idit-harel-caperton|title=Dr. Idit Harel Caperton: Huffington Post Author Page|accessdate=September 15, 2014}} Harel was the founder and CEO of [[MaMaMedia]] Inc., the executive director of the MaMaMedia Consulting Group (MCG), and the founder, President, and Chair of the [http://www.worldwideworkshop.org World Wide Workshop], [[educational technology]] development companies. She is presently the CEO and a founding Chair of [[Globaloria]],{{cite web|url=http://www.worldwideworkshop.org/about-us/board-of-directors|title=World Wide Workshop: Board of Directors|accessdate=August 3, 2015}} which designs computer learning programs for K-12 schools in the United States. ==Personal life== Idit Ron was born in [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]]. Her parents and their families are Holocaust survivors from Poland and Czechoslovakia. She married her first husband, [[David Harel]], in 1979 (divorced 1995); they have three children. She married her second husband, former [[West Virginia]] governor [[Gaston Caperton]], in 2003; they divorced in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://redefineschool.com/idit-harel-caperton|title=Idit Harel Caperton profile|accessdate=August 3, 2015}} ==Career== ===Education=== Harel moved to the [[United States]] in 1982 for graduate study at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Education]] after having previously received a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Psychology]] and [[Philosophy]] from [[Tel-Aviv University]]. She earned two graduate degrees from [[Harvard University|Harvard]]: an EdM in Technology in Education (1984) and a Certificate of Advanced Graduate Studies (CAS) in Human Development (1985) from the Harvard Graduate School of Education. In 1988, she earned a Ph.D in Epistemology and Learning Research from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] after helping to formulate a new constructivist model with Seymour Papert, the "Instructional Software Design Learning Paradigm."{{cite web|title=Dr. Idit Harel – Founder and CEO, Globaloria|url=http://www.tribecadisruptiveinnovationawards.com/idit-harel|accessdate=August 3, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160811164042/http://www.tribecadisruptiveinnovationawards.com/idit-harel/|archivedate=August 11, 2016|df=}} ===Children Designers=== Harel's research at the Harvard Graduate School of Education and the MIT Media Lab in the 1980s led to the 1991 publication of ''Children Designers'', which won the 1991 ''Outstanding Book Award'' from the [[American Education Research Association]], with an introduction by Harel's research collaborator, constructivist researcher Seymour Papert. ''Children Designers'' presents the results of Harel's research in which she introduced disadvantaged fourth-grade children from the Boston area to the [[Logo programming language]], and facilitated their creation of mathematical software applications that would help third-grade peers learn fractions. ''Children Designers'' suggested implementations within schools that emphasize this project-based and student-centered approach.{{cite journal|first=Idit|last=Harel| year=1990|title=Children as software designers: a constructionist approach for learning mathematics|journal=The Journal of Mathematical Behavior|volume=9|issue=1|page=4}} ===MaMaMedia=== {{main|MaMaMedia}} In 1995, Harel moved to New York City, where she founded MaMaMedia, an Internet [[Dot-com company|dot-com]] that offered web services focused on inculcating digital literacy and creative learning skills among children and their parents who used the web games and activities offered.{{cite web|title=Company Overview of MaMaMedia Inc.|publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=534587|accessdate=August 22, 2013}} Harel developed MaMaMedia based largely on her research in the MIT Media Lab in the educational principles of constructionism. The site provided web users with a range of "playful learning" activities and projects,{{cite web|title=MaMaMedia.com helps families explore Web|publisher=The Rock River Times|url=http://rockrivertimes.com/1993/07/01/mamamediacom-helps-families-explore-web|date=July 1, 1993|accessdate=August 22, 2013}} publishing the first print [[magazine]] for children about the Internet, ''MaMaMedia: A Kid's Guide to the Net''.{{cite web|title=MaMaMedia: A Kid's Guide to the Web|publisher=MaMaMedia.com|url=http://www.mamamedia.com/activities/magonline/home.html|accessdate=August 22, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000229214236/http://mamamedia.com/activities/magonline/home.html|archivedate=February 29, 2000|df=}} ===World Wide Workshop and Globaloria=== {{main|Globaloria}} Harel founded World Wide Workshop in 2004, a [[501(c)(3)]] non-profit organization that develops applications for learning with technology that combine game design and online social media experiences for youth to empower them to be inventors and leaders in the global knowledge economy. The foundation's programs aim to transform education by connecting youth to technology learning opportunities in schools and community centers, facilitating children's localized community engagement, and fostering the potential for economic development through game production experiences.{{cite web|last=Bracey Sutton|first=Bonnie|first2=Vic|last2=Sutton|date=August 30, 2010|url=http://etcjournal.com/2010/08/30/idit-harel-caperton-an-interview|title=Idit Harel Caperton – An Interview at the Edge of Change|accessdate=August 3, 2015|publisher=education, technology & change}} Globaloria is a social learning system and educational program of the World Wide Workshop, in which participating students engage in a range of digital activities.{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/stem-education/2012/03/19/high-quality-stem-education-for-all-it-takes-a-village|title=High-Quality STEM Education for All: It Takes a Village and global citizenship through game design.|last=Harel Caperton|first=Idit|publisher=U.S. News & World Report|date=March 19, 2012}} The program was established in 2006 to cultivate both students' and educators' 21st century skills and digital literacy, facilitating mastery of social media technology tools, and students' deeper understanding of curricular areas, such as science, mathematics and health.{{cite web|url=http://alum.mit.edu/pages/sliceofmit/2013/02/13/alumna-develops-educational-game-changer|title=Alumna Develops Educational Game Changer|last=Marcott|first=Amy|publisher=MIT: Slice of Life|date=February 13, 2013}} ==Research and theories== ===Clickerati=== Much of Harel's published work in the 1990s and early 2000s focused on the emergence of what she has termed the "Clickerati Generation" - children born since 1991 who will grow up immersed in new media, and unable to imagine a world without Internet technology. She calls for a radical paradigm shift in the education and acculturation of this generation, emphasizing normalization of digital information and communication, and the cultivation of digital literacy skills for their successful development, citizenship, and leadership within such physical-digital blended environments.{{cite journal|first=Idit|last=Harel|date=Spring 2002|title=Learning New-Media Literacy: A New Necessity for the Young Clickerati Generation|journal=Telemedium|volume=48|issue=1|pages=17–26}}{{cite journal|first=Idit|last=Harel|date=March 1997|title=Clickerati Kids: Who Are They?|journal=21st Century Learning}} ===Constructionist MOOCs=== Through the launch of the World Wide Workshop and research on its flagship program Globaloria, Harel has advanced the use of [[constructionist learning]] within the MOOC model. She has criticized MOOCs for generally replicating the instructor-led learning model, and asserts that Globaloria's educational tools are the only constructionist MOOCs for middle and high school students, and that this approach is unique in simultaneously training teachers and instructors on a [[blended learning]] model.{{cite web|first=Idit|last=Harel Caperton|title=Opinion: Before We Flip Classrooms, Let's Re-Think What We're Flipping To|url=http://www.wiredacademic.com/2012/10/opinion-before-we-flip-classrooms-lets-re-think-what-were-flipping-to|publisher=WiredAcademic|date=October 18, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2015}}{{cite web|first=Paul|last=Glader|title=Interview: Globaloria Founder Dr. Idit Harel Caperton On Video Games As The New Language Arts|url=http://www.wiredacademic.com/2011/12/interview-globaloria-founder-dr-idit-harel-caperton-on-video-games-as-the-new-language-arts|publisher=WiredAcademic|date=December 14, 2011|accessdate=August 3, 2015}} ==Honors== *2015: Symmetry 50 "Top Women in NYC Startups"{{cite web|title=The Top Women in NYC Startups|publisher=Symmetry50|url=http://www.symmetry50.com/blog/2015/3/3/the-top-women-in-new-york-startups|accessdate=August 7, 2015}} *2013: Named to Disruptor Foundation Fellows{{cite web|title=The Disruptor Foundation Fellows|url=http://www.tribecadisruptiveinnovationawards.com/the-disruptor-foundation-fellows|publisher=Tribeca Disruptive Innovation Awards|accessdate=August 26, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101064608/http://www.tribecadisruptiveinnovationawards.com/the-disruptor-foundation-fellows/|archivedate=November 1, 2013|df=}} *2012: Journal of Media Literacy Special Issue guest editor: Globaloria{{cite web|title=World Wide Workshop - Press Archive|url=http://worldwideworkshop.org/press/press-archive#journal_media_literacy_december_2012}} *2011: Named to Digital Learning Council by Digital Learning Now!{{cite web|title=History - Digital Learning Now!|url=http://digitallearningnow.com/about/history/|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} *2010: Jessie McCanse Award for Individual Contribution to Media Literacy, by the National Telemedia Council.{{cite web|title=Dr. Idit Harel: Biography|url=http://exposednyc.com/speaker/idit-harel/|publisher=EXPOSED NYC|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} *2002: Network of Educators in Science and Technology (NEST) recognized for "devotion, innovation, and imagination in science and technology on behalf of children and youth around the world.",{{cite web|title=Idit Harel Caperton - An Interview|url=http://etcjournal.com/2010/08/30/idit-harel-caperton-an-interview/|publisher=Educational Technology & Change|accessdate=5 August 2015}} [[Computerworld Smithsonian Award]] for Media, Arts and Entertainment: MaMaMedia Peace Project{{cite web|title=Computerworld Honors Award Recipients|url=http://www.cwhonors.org/search/caa_5.asp|accessdate=August 7, 2015}} *1999: ComputerworldSmithsonian Award for Education: MaMaMedia Internet-centered products for young children and their families *1992: Outstanding Book Award for Children Designers, by the [[American Education Research Association]] (AERA).{{cite web|title=AERA Outstanding Book Award|url=http://www.aera.net/AboutAERA/Awards/OutstandingBookAward/tabid/12782/Default.aspx|accessdate=August 7, 2015}} *1990: Journal of Mathematical Behavior - Outstanding Dissertation Issue: "Interdisciplinary Constructions of Learning and Knowing Mathematics in a Computer-Rich School." ==Bibliography== *"Constructionism: Research Reports and Essays, 1985-1990", 1991 (with Seymour Papert) *"Children Designers: Interdisciplinary Constructions for Learning and Knowing Mathematics in a Computer-rich School", 1991. *"Constructionist Learning: A 5th Anniversary Collection of Papers Reflecting Research Reports, Projects in Progress, and Essays by the Epistemology & Learning Group", 1990. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/idit-harel-caperton/ Idit Harel Caperton's blog], huffingtonpost.com; accessed August 7, 2015 * [http://www.iditharel.com Personal website] * [http://audio.edtechlive.com/foe/idit.mp3 Interview on Future of Education podcast], March 12, 2013 * [http://www.wiredacademic.com/2011/12/interview-globaloria-founder-dr-idit-harel-caperton-on-video-games-as-the-new-language-arts Idit Harel Caperton on Video Games as the New Language Arts], wiredacademic.com, December 14, 2011 * [http://mediasnackers.com/2008/02/mediasnackers-podcast104 Idit Harel Caperton profile], mediasnackers.com, February 2008; accessed August 7, 2015 (interview with Monica Larson of Shephard University), October 21, 2009 * {{YouTube|meCjTMCttdY|Interview at the Digital Learning & Design Conference}}, January 27, 2008 {{DEFAULTSORT:Harel, Idit}}
